Comment: One of the things that has been bothering me about some of these rulings is that they ignore a longstanding principle of legal analysis and interpretation - when your interpretation of the law suggests absurd results, then the analysis is incorrect. The law and its interpretation is not intended and has never functioned such that a legal interpretation would bring absurd results. While that rule of interpretation must be balanced by the parallel rule that one must give effect to all aspects of a particular text, it’s a rule that has stood for hundreds of years, going well back into our English Common Law roots. This has that feel to me - an interpretation of the law that suggests that the President lacks authority to even temporarily suspend a specific executive function with immediate effect, much less one involving the ability to control who is able to enter the country seems patently absurd to me. It defies common sense. While I understand the harm analysis here, I think this is an area where simple logic dictates that the President would have nearly unlimited authority to do this.
